context_meta.title: Disney Officially Acquires Most Of Fox In $66.1 Billion Buyout. Here's What They Got
context_meta.summary: The Walt Disney Company has announced — along with some pretty big news from Disney CEO Bob Iger — their official acquisition of most of 21st Century Fox, a deal that has been long rumored and much discussed. The $66.1 billion buyout — paid with $52.4 billion in Disney stock and assumption of all debt owed by Fox — includes 20th Century Fox, Fox Searchlight Pictures, Fox 2000, 20th Century Fox Television, FX Productions, Fox21, FX Networks, National Geographic Partners, Fox Sports Regional Networks, Fox Networks Group International, and Star India.

context_meta.title: Allison Janney auditioned three birds for 'I, Tonya'
context_meta.summary: In “I, Tonya,” Allison Janney plays LaVona Golden, mother of figure skater Tonya Harding, who would become embroiled in the scandal surrounding the 1994 attack on another skater, Nancy Kerrigan. In the film, the contentious relationship between Harding and Golden becomes a big part of the story and Harding's motivation for success at skating. A real-life documentary interview with Harding's mother formed the basis for scenes in the movie, in which she talks directly to the camera with a small pet bird on her shoulder.  During the Envelope Roundtable for supporting actresses, Janney talked about auditioning three birds for the part and how the calm bird picked for the role wasn't so calm on shooting

context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: Star Wars: The Last Jedi spoilers – the big questions, answered
context_meta.summary: Warning: contains major spoilers Have you seen Star Wars: The Last Jedi? If you haven’t, this spoiler-filled article probably isn’t going to be for you (and trust us: Episode Eight boasts some jaw-droppingly good moments, all ripe for spoiling). But if you’re up to date with the latest events in a galaxy far, far away, here’s a quick round up of some of the big questions Rian Johnson’s film has left us with.  1. What's happened to the Force? Have the rules completely changed?  It’s not so much a case of rules being broken, and more a case of existing expectations being blown apart and pre-established boundaries challenged. But either way, in The Last Jedi Johnson is clearly having a blast with the idea of what the Force can and can’t do. There’s a raw physicality to those bridging scenes between Rey and Kylo Ren, for instance, that transcends traditional Force telepathy: a sense of “crossing over”, opening a window and really reaching through. True, we later learn that the intense bond between the pair has been engineered by Snoke for his own purposes (and it’s not clear exactly how he does this). Without getting too metaphysical, it’s also worth noting that all physical sensations arguably take place in the mind: Rey and Kylo might feel as if they’re being touched, or remotely attacked, without these actions really taking place. But the fact remains that The Force, in this film, feels more potent, more unexpected – and, given these new developments, more viscerally frightening – than ever before. 2. How can Luke suddenly have the power of astral projection? Well, possibly not anymore, as Luke is now pretty definitely dead (see question nine). But his extended projection scene in The Last Jedi was another example of the way Johnson has pushed his definition of Force powers to the limit, showing us things we’ve never before seen in a Star Wars movie. Interestingly, there is some precedent for these kind of powers in some of the (non-canon) Star Wars comic books. In the series Dark Empire, for instance, Luke is able to create a projected double of himself and use it to fool others – and, in other stories, it’s established that a kind of astral projection can be used by certain Jedi and Sith, although not that often. But Johnson’s decision to kill Luke off immediately after his ruse – implying that the effort involved has taken all his strength – suggests that Luke’s extended accomplishment, in the world of the films, may have been a one-off, never-before-attempted feat. Star Wars | More from The Telegraph 3. Just how powerful is Leia? We already know, from previous films, that Leia “has the Force” (You have that power too,” Luke tells her in Return of the Jedi. “In time you’ll learn to use it”). And yet, because it’s something we’ve not really seen in any detail on the big-screen before, the scene in which the General guides herself back to the safety of her ship, evading an icy death in space, feels incredibly important. Carrie Fisher as Leia Sadly, while we’d normally be speculating about whether we’d be seeing more of Leia’s powers in Episode Nine, the untimely death of Carrie Fisher last year means that this now feels unlikely. Lucasfilm has promised that a resurrected CGI Leia definitely isn’t on the cards – and plans to focus on the character in the final film will have been adjusted accordingly. 4. Are Rey’s parents really “nobodies”? The revelation that Rey’s parents were a pair of heartless nobodies, who callously sold their daughter then met their deaths shortly afterwards, was one of the film’s most brilliantly subversive twists. It’s possible that Kylo may have been lying to Rey, attempting to manipulate her into joining him – but his revelation that she really did come from nothing had a ring of truth to it. Furthermore, in a franchise that has previously traded on secret identities and mystery fathers, the concept that Rey is special just because she’s Rey – and not because she’s so-and-so’s daughter – feels oddly affirming. Daisy Ridley as Rey Rey doesn’t need to have a hidden, “chosen one” heritage – she’s powerful and important in her own right, because of her strength, and her courage, and her resolution. Our private guess, for what it’s worth, is that Kylo was only half-lying: we reckon it’ll turn out that Rey’s parents were indeed nobodies – but quite nice ones, who always intended to come back for their daughter. This way, she’ll still get some bittersweet emotional resolution, without compromising the important message that a “nobody” can still be a Force-wielding force to be reckoned with. 5. Who, exactly, was Snoke? And does it matter? And what, we might add, was going on with that gold dressing gown? Terrible look, Snoke. You’re much more intimidating as a giant hologram. In retrospect, of course, the decision to make the Supreme Leader seem weaker – shrunken, and somehow substantially diminished in grandeur and menace – in this film was probably all part of Johnson’s plan, building up as it does to the moment in which the former arch-villain makes a fatal miscalculation. Now that he’s been neatly sliced in two, however, all the feverish speculation about his “real” identity” that fans were previously indulging in feels a bit pointless. Andy Serkis as Snoke We imagine the story of Snoke’s past might be explored, someday, in a Star Wars spin-off title. But now that he’s out of the picture, it feels highly unlikely that his background will form a major plot point in Episode Nine – or that a big, game-changing reveal was ever on the cards. Snoke, safe to say, is nobody’s daddy. 6. Are Hux’s days numbered? Ah, poor Hux. Conflicted Kylo might flicker between evil and good, but his space Nazi buddy has always been properly committed to the Dark Side. And yet, despite his appropriately villainous voice and looks – and infantile lack of temper tantrums – Hux is now stuck playing second fiddle to Kylo, simmering with resentment while the new Supreme Leader throws out ridiculous, emotionally impulsive orders. Domhnall Gleeson as Hux His barely disguised loathing – and Kylo’s rampant instability – mean that Hux will probably make a new bid for power and meet his end early on in Episode Nine. We hope, for his sake, he gets to blow up a few planets or something first. 7. Could Rey and Kylo Ren end up switching roles? All this barely concealed Force-flirting and reluctant emotional bonding can’t end well, can it? They might share a mysterious connection, but now that Kylo has apparently chosen his path, it feels unlikely that the series has a happy ending in store for him and Rey. The rogue Solo son, furthermore, is also now the main villain of the piece (sorry Hux), meaning that any redemption arc would have to take place pretty late in the game, or risk taking away all the stakes. Adam Driver as Kylo Ren One just-about-plausible twist is that Episode Nine will see Rey explore her own dark side and turn antagonist – something which was strongly hinted at in her Last Jedi scenes with Luke, in which he sensed her terrifying potential for darkness. Overall, however, it feels as if the franchise, under Johnson’s direction, could be more interested in the idea of finding balance, and carving out a world where the light and dark extremes of the Force must both take backseat. The emergence of a new generation of Force-sensitive characters (as evidenced by that final scene with the little boy) could also play into this. 8. Was there a subtle “let’s be nicer to animals” message at play? If so, it’s a message we’re thoroughly on board with. We had Chewbacca getting guilt-tripped by a sad porg while eating a roasted porg – I mean really, Chewie: how could you? – and some surprisingly sympathetic, intelligent-seeming ice crystal foxes, on hand to help the rebellion out of a tight spot. Chewbacca and a porg There was even an apparent anti- animal racing sub plot, courtesy of the casino scenes (take home lesson: whipping things and making them race each other is mean, no matter how glamorous or fun it might look at first). That said, when it comes to sheer pathos, nothing will ever rival the grieving Rancor keeper. 9. Is Luke definitely dead? Will he come back as a Force ghost in Episode Nine? We’re going to go out on a limb here and say yes and yes. Body disappearing under a cloak like that? Classic Jedi-who-will-probably-be-a-ghost-death. In case you’re wondering, the standard Star Wars explanation for the ghosts is that certain Jedi, such as Yoda and Obi Wan, have mastered the art of becoming one with the Force at death, while simultaneously maintaining their individuality. Mark Hamill as Luke Skywalker Previous films and materials suggested that doing this was something that had to be taught – but, during his years of self-imposed solitude, it’s perfectly plausible that Luke may have come across the technique, or even been schooled in it by ghost-Yoda. Without being too cynical, it also feels likely that Episode Nine will want to maintain a link to at least one of the three veteran actors from the original trilogy. With Harrison Ford’s Han Solo meeting his end in The Force Awakens, and Carrie Fisher tragically passing away in 2016, a future Luke ghost cameo feels like a fairly safe bet. 10. ​Have the “rules” for Force ghosts changed? In previous Star Wars movies, Force ghosts haven’t really been able to do that much. They can turn up to Ewok parties, yes – but interacting with the real world (or grabbing a slice of barbecued Stormtrooper) always appeared to be out of the question. In The last Jedi, however, Yoda appears to have physical form; he was able to start a fire, gleefully burn some ancient Jedi texts and actively engage with Luke’s surroundings. All suggesting that Johnson may have chosen to shake things up a bit, or at least test the rules surrounding the ghosts and their physicality.

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: Space capsule with 3 astronauts returns to Earth
context_meta.summary: MOSCOW –  Three astronauts have landed back on Earth after nearly six months aboard the International Space Station. A Russian Soyuz capsule with NASA's Randy Bresnik, Russia's Sergey Ryazanskiy and Paolo Nespoli of the European Space Agency descended under a red-and-white parachute and landed on schedule at 2:37 p.m. local time (0837 GMT; 3:37 a.m. EST) on the vast steppes outside of a remote town in Kazakhstan. The three were extracted from the capsule within 20 minutes and appeared to be in good condition. Bresnik, Ryazansky and Nespoli spent 139 days aboard the orbiting space laboratory.

Wilson praised Kay Cannon, who wrote all three “Pitch Perfect” movies, for creating genuine characters. She added that “friendship and empowerment themes” will resonate with both male and female audiences. context_meta.summary: When writer-director Alex Garland read Annihilation, the bestselling science-fiction novel by Jeff VanderMeer, the filmmaker was struck by the sensation of being inside a dream. “What I did was, I took a really weird approach to the adaptation,” Garland, whose last film was the sci-fi sleeper hit Ex Machina, exclusivelyexplained to Yahoo Entertainment. In other words, Garland committed to an unfaithful adaptation, using VanderMeer’s work as inspiration (with the novelist’s blessing).

context_meta.title: Costco teamed up with MoviePass to get you an absurdly cheap cinema subscription
context_meta.summary: Movie fans who wished for a Netflix-like service for going to the cinema have at least one such subscription-based product. Launched this summer, Moviepass costs $10 per month, and lets you watch as many new movie releases as you want. That’s incredibly affordable, and the price dropped even lower than $10 per month a few weeks ago. And now the company has an even better offer for you. MoviePass on Tuesday announced that it partnered with Fandor and Costco to offer buyers a combined yearly subscription for just $89.99. The offer is valid only online at Costco.com, and once you purchase it, you’ll be given codes that activate your one-year MoviePass and Fandor subscriptions. That’s an incredible deal considering that Fandor would typically cost $5 per month. Fandor is a streaming service for independent movies, documentaries, international features, and shorts, and the flat $89.99 package will give you access to all of Fandor’s 5,000+ titles. Even if you don’t care about Fandor, this deal will get you a year worth of MoviePass access for $20 less than what the subscription costs through MoviePass. Don’t look anywhere else for this deal, as Costco is the exclusive seller. Furthermore, the offer is valid from December 12th through December 18th, so you’ll have to hurry. Finally, if you’re looking to give friends and family MoviePass gifts, such an option is available over at MoviePass. But you’d still be better activating a MoviePass subscription for them through Costco.
